questions.text: A 53-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is found on annual review to have new vessel formation at the optic disc. Visual acuity in both eyes is not affected (6/9). Blood pressure is155/84 mmHg. HbA1c 68 mmol/mol (8.4%) What is the most important intervention in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of PDR as NVD is here in the pt.
  • So PRP ( laser ) is the only treatment of choice

questions.text: A 65 year old presented o you foreign body sensation since many years. He had episodes of redness also since early childhood. There is no systemic illness. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: It shows extra row of eyelash

choices.text: Done by double freq Nd Yag laser
Treatment of choice for angle closure glaucoma
Done in mid peripheral part of iris
Useful when adhesions in angle are less

questions.text: What is incorrect about this procedure ?
questions.solution:
This is peripheral iriodotomy

Done by Nd YAG laser, not by Df Nd YAG

Useful for synchie are less than 180 degree

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency room complaining of acute onset blurry vision through his left eye (OS). He also described binocular horizontal diplopia, which was worse when looking to the right. Upon waking up that day, he felt he was experiencing a typical ocular migraine, and headache He also had a stroke in 2013. On check up vertical movements were normal, on left gaze a jerk nystagmus was seen on left side. Where is the site of lesion
questions.solution:
• R MLF lesion will cause a R internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)
  • It will cause R sided jerk nystagmus on attempted abduction

choices.text: Quantitate macular edema and treat with laser OR injections
Measure the amount of hemorrhage and treat them

questions.text: Treatment for CRVO
questions.solution: In CRVO, hemorhage will settle down themselves. The treatment is done for CME only. So an OCT is done, then treatment is decided whether anti VEGFs are to be planned or laser

choices.text: Non Necrotising scleritis in seropositive rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: Scleromalacia perforance is
questions.solution:
SCLEROMALACIA PERFORANS


  • Type III hypersensitivity reaction , anterior necrotizing scleritis without inflammation
  • Typically occurs in elderly women with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. SLE, PAN, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Behçet disease, herpes-zoster are also associated
  • Absence of pain, almost normal vision, scleral thinning, staphyloma are seen.
  • Obliteration of arterial supply and sequestrum formation

questions.text: An elderly female was admitted with serious COVID infection since 7 days. She developed a painful ophthalmoplegia as shown in figure. Biopsy revealed broad aseptate fungal hyphae with sporangium. What can be the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
MUCORMYCOSIS



  • Life threatening complication, serious angioinvasive infection by mucormycetes.
  • Inhalation of spores - infection in sinus, lungs, brain and eye
  • Risk factors-
  • Types - rhino-orbito-cerebal, pulmonary, cutaneous, G/I, diseeminated
  • Rate of incidence - 0.005 - 1.7/million
  • India - 140/ million

C/F: nasal congestion, headache, lethargy, fever, facial swelling, BL proptosis, slurred speech, black lesion, hemoptysis

Diagnosis - CT guided Bx, Broncho-alveoloar lavage ( BAL), KOH mount, CT scan , culture with PCR

Treatment - Liopsomal Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is false about ICRS
questions.solution:
INTRA CORNEAL RING SEGMENTS : ICRS - INTACS


  • Made up of PPMA, 2 semicircular concentric rings.
  • Placed in stroma by help of femto lasers
  • Corrects irregularities of cornea, flattening of cornea
  • Used for myopia upto 8 D, keratoconus
  • Surgical procedure can be reversed
  • Not used for dystrophy

questions.text: What level of vision quantifies a patient to be labelled as economically blind ?
questions.solution:
• Economic - <6/60 - 3/60
  • Social - < 3/60 - 1/60
  • Manifest - <1/60 to PL
  • Absolute - no PL

choices.text: Absence of sweating on same side of face

questions.text: A patient is found to have a mild ptosis which he reports to have since birth. There is also change in the color of iris of the same eye. What is not likely feature associated with this condition
questions.solution:
There is a meiosis not mydriasis


Horner's syndrome

  • HI PAMELA (pneumonic)
  • HI HETEROCHROMIA IRIDIUM
  • P PTOSIS (MILD) due to muller dysfunction
  • A ANHYDROSIS
  • M MEIOSIS (due to absence of dilator muscle function)
  • E ENOPHTALMOS (apparent)
  • L LOSS OF CILIOSPINAL REFELX
  • A ANISOCORIA (INCREASE IN DARK)

questions.text: Pattern shown in FFA picture
questions.solution:
This is ink blot pattern in CSR

CSR

questions.text: A 24 year old patient presents with congestion, itching, FB sensation in eye. He has a history of contact lens usage. What is not in you list of suspicion ?
questions.solution:
• VKC is not related to contact lens usage
  • Rather it is seen in children in the first decade due to hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE by exogenous allergen

questions.text: A farmer presented with pain, photophobia and watering from eye since last 36 hours. O/E, 1 x2 cm ulcer is seen as shown in image. Identify the lesion marked
questions.solution: • This arrow shows ring infiltrate (i.e immunological ring of Weissley - a junction of antigen and antibody reaction)

questions.text: Which of the following is the not associated with this anomaly of eye
questions.solution:
The picture shows subluxation of lens

This is not seen in down syndrome

The other conditions where subluxation can be seen is

  • (B P L M E H S H) Below Poverty Line ME Hum Subluxate Hue (pneumonic)
  • Buphthalmos, Pseudoexfoliation, hyperLysenemia, Marfan,
  • weil Marchensani syndrome, EhlerDanlos syndrome, Homocysteinuria, Sulphite oxidase deficiency, HMSC

questions.text: A female presented with a sudden painless loss of vision. She has no history of DM/ hypertension. On examination direct and consensual light reflex are normal. Retina also shows no changes but her VEP is subnormal. What is your provisional diagnosis
questions.solution:
• If VEP is subnormal then it has to be a cortical blindness
  • Cortical blindness (CB) is defined as loss of vision without any ophthalmological causes and with normal pupillary light reflexes due to bilateral lesions of the striate cortex in the occipital lobes.
  • A complete loss of visual sensation and of vision
  • Preservation/sparing of the abilities to perceive light and/or moving, but not static objects (Riddoch syndrome)
  • A lack of visual fixation and tracking
  • Denial of visual loss (Anton-Babinski syndrome)
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Macular sparing, in which vision in the fovea is spared from the blindness

choices.text: Removal by 26 G needle under slit lamp

questions.text: A 20 year male came with redness photophobia and foreign body sensation since a day. On examination something was found on cornea. What is the next step
questions.solution: • This picture shows a corneal FB, to be removed by 26G needle under slit lamp after anesthetizing the cornea

choices.text: Watering may be seen in the newborn baby
Surgery can be the best treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the picture given below
questions.solution:
Blepharospasm, Phtophobia, Lacrimation (TRIAD)

  • B P L pneumonic - ymptoms
  • This is a case of congenital glaucoma
  • The AC will be rather deep
  • Anterior chamber is shallow
  • Signs
    • Cornea is large and hazy
    • AC deep, lens is large and flat
    • Eye ball is large (buphthalmos)
    • High IOP, MYOPIA, haab s striae can be seen

Management of buphthalmos

  1. Goniotomy
  2. Trabeculotomy + trabeculectomy : cutting a part of TM and open the remaining also

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented to OPD with double vision and drooping of eyelid . She is an IT engineer and tends to have more symptoms in post lunch session. What can be the most probable diagnosis if she there is an improvement in her symptoms on applying ice.
questions.solution:
• Ice pack test - improvement in ptosis when ice is applied on eyelid, as on low temperatures, acetylcholine - esterase enzyme is inhibited so more Ach is available for LPS muscle to contract
  • Hence ptosis improves

choices.text: Loss of sensation in V2 region
Diplopia is both on looking up and down
The blow is usually by an object slightly smaller or same size of orbital aperture

questions.text: What is not true about orbital blow out fracture
questions.solution:
• The blow is usually by an object should be rather slightly larger or same size of orbital aperture

Double diplopia is the presenting compliant

Enophthalmos may occur later as orbital soft tissue prolapse into the maxillary sinus from the defect

questions.text: A 15 month old baby was brought to pediatric department with fever, cough. Lethargy. The baby hasn't started walking also. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and BL lungs crackles. He was referred to an ophthalmologist to rule out cherry red spot. The pediatrician is suspecting a disorder where sphingomyelin are deposited in organs. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Neimann pick diease -
  • AR, def of enzyme sphingomyelinase
  • Sphingomylein acculumulates in various organs
  • 3 types
  • Liver spleen CNS lungs
  • MR, CRS, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Sandhoff disease - Def of beta hexosaminidase - lipids are accumulated in brain and other organs

choices.text: It is a mild grade panuveitis
It can occur as a atypical uveitis with trabeculitis
Eyes are very red with pupil dilated

questions.text: A 40 year old man came with blurred vision since morning. He also described mild headache. IOP was 60 mmHg, AC shows minimum cells. What can be the correct statement regarding his diagnosis
questions.solution:
This is a case of Posner Schlossmann syndrome.

Atypical uveitis with minimal inflammation. Very high IOP not correlating with inflammation

Seen in young adults, idiopathic.

Trabeculitis leads to inflammation and high IOP

questions.text: A patient came with a history of trauma near eye. He also reports the vision is dropped since then. You have examined the patient and this was the picture. Vision is just FCCF and IOP is 40 mmHg. He is also a known case of sickle cell anaemia. Which drug would be best avoided in him
questions.solution:
• This is a case of hyphema after trauma. Collection of blood in AC.
  • Avoid oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, especially acetazolamide (eg, Diamox), in patients with sickle cell trait or disease. These drugs tend to increase sickling of erythrocytes and worsen the situation

questions.text:
A 40 year old male came with redness pain in left eye since 2 days. On examination the pupil were constricted and iris details was hazily seen. On enquiring he gave a history of backache and showed an X ray.

What is the best treatment plan for his eye condition
questions.solution:
• Topical steroids and cyclolegics
  • This is a case of Ankylosing spondylitis with anterior uveitis
  • It is a HLA B 27 related arthropathy
  • It can be associated with AAU (acute anterior uveitis)
  • So the treatment of choice here is topical steroids and cycloplegic

choices.text: Indirect ophthalmoscopy to see retinal changes should be done
The earliest sign for his condition is conjunctival xerosis
Vitamin A1 lac IU should be given to him stat

questions.text: An 8year old boy living in a remote village, presented with his mother in OPD with difficulty in vision during evening hours as explained by mother as frequent falls during his playing hours in evening. On examination his vision was 6/6 in both eyes. But anterior segment shows this picture. He appeared to be malnourished also. What is not correct in this regard
questions.solution:
Vitamin A 1 lac IU should be given to him stat

This is a picture showing conjunctival xerosis in xerophthalmia

As this child is more than 1 year, the prescribed dosage of vitamin A is 2 lack IU orally or 1 lack IU IM

questions.text:
A 60 year old female came with decreased vision of both eye. On examination vision is 6/24 and 6,18. Anterior segment is normal with IOP of 18 mmHg in BE . There is a history of chronic arthritis since last 20 years. The drug history is not available. Fundus shows this picture.

What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• CQ and HCQ bind to melanin in RPE and cause damage to cones in the macula. They inhibit RPE phagocytosis function causing accumulation of shed photoreceptors in the outer segment
  • Usually not reversible.
  • May lead to permanent damage

Other manifestations of CQ toxicity

  • Whorl deposits
  • Macular pigmentation
  • PSC
  • Hudson stahli line

choices.text: Earliest seen on gonioscopy and AS OCT

questions.text: All are true about this picture except
questions.solution:
• Wilson disease and KF ring
  • Cu accumulation in DM of cornea, Starts at superior part
  • Vision normal. Disappear after treatment
  • Other causes of KF rings are cholestasis, primary biliary cirrhosisand "cryptogenic" cirrhosis.
  • May also be seen in chalcosis
  • Ceruloplasmin is decreased in 85-90% of individuals, 24-hour urinary copper and free copper will show increased copper level.
  • Seen under slit lamp, gonioscopy and AS OCT is done for early diagnosis

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child presents with a picture like the. What is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is leukocoria (abnormal white pupillary reflex)
  • Not seen in congenital glaucoma

France TRIP to CDR

  • Fungal endophthalmitis
  • Toxocariasis
  • ROP
  • Inflammatory cyclitic membrane
  • PHPV
  • Congenital cataract, coat's disease, coloboma
  • Dysplasia of retina
  • Retinoblastoma

choices.text: Can opener capsulorhexis with methylene blue dye

questions.text: What is this step in phaco surgery and what is the stain used
questions.solution:
• This is Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorhexis is done in anterior lens capsule
  • Stained by trypan blue dye


Dyes

  • Fluorescein

  • Rose Bengal dye

questions.text: Which investigation is being done here
questions.solution:
• This is Goldman applanation Tonometer ( GAT) - best for IOP measurement as most accurate reading is given by it.
  • It is based on fick law P = F/A
  • Fixed area 3.04 mm /7.02 mm2
  • Anaesthetize cornea with proparacaine, stain with fluorescein → under cobalt blue filter of slit lamp biprism advanced towards cornea → touches apex→ 2 semicircles observed → end point

questions.text: What is the muscle responsible for Levo depression
questions.solution:
• Levodepression is looking left and down
  • Understood by the picture given below

Nine diagnostic positions of gaze are those in which deviations are measured. They consist of the six cardinal positions, the primary position, elevation and depression.

Positions of gaze

  • Six cardinal positions of gaze are identified in which one muscle in each eye is principally responsible for moving the eye into that position
  • Dextroversion (right lateral rectus and left medial rectus).
  • Levoversion (left lateral rectus and right medial rectus).
  • Dextroelevation (right superior rectus and left inferior oblique).
  • Levoelevation (left superior rectus and right inferior oblique).
  • Dextrodepression (right inferior rectus and left superior oblique).
  • Levodepression (left inferior rectus and right superior oblique).

choices.text: The pupil doesn't react to the light but it is reacting to the convergence
The pupil reacts to light but does not accommodate

questions.text: How is Argyll Robertson pupil defined?
questions.solution:
• Argyll Robertson pupils are caused by neurosyphilis
  • Dorsal midbrain lesion that interrupts the pupillary light reflex pathway but spares the more ventral pupillary near reflex pathway - light-near dissociation results.
  • In dim light both pupils are small and may be irregular.
  • In bright light neither pupil constricts, but on accommodation (near target) both constrict.
  • After instillation of pilocarpine 0.1% into both eyes, neither pupil constricts, distinguishing Argyll Robertson pupils from bilateral longstanding tonic pupils.

choices.text: Early and specific VF defect is isopteric contraction
For monitoring glaucoma VF defects kinetic perimetry is best
In static perimetry the stimulus is moving with variable intensity
VF defects are associated with ONH changes in the optic nerve

questions.text: Which of type following is true about open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
• VF defects are associated with ONH changes in the optic nerve
  • The picture below shows that when we have ON changes usually the VF changes corelate.

choices.text: Ishihara is used for checking Deutranopia

questions.text: True about color vision is all except
questions.solution:
ISHIHARA CHART


  • Monochromat
  • Dichromat
  • Trichromat
  • Dichromat can be
    • Protanopia
    • Deutranopia
    • Tritanopia
  • Trichromats
    • Protanomaly
    • Deutranomaly
    • Tritanomaly
  • Ishihara charts can be used to check red and green color defects. Not blue
  • And tritanomaly is blue color defects which are not checked by Ishihara

choices.text: Excimer laser is used after femtolaser
Not suitable for very high myopia
Visual outcome comparable to other refractive surgeries

questions.text: What is not true about this surgery
questions.solution:
This is a picture of Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE). It is a relatively new refractive procedure designed to treat refractive errors such as myopia, hyperopia, presbyopia, and astigmatism.

The procedure involves using a femtosecond laser to create a corneal lenticule which is extracted whole through a small incision without the use of an excimer laser.

Excimer laser is used for stromal thinning in cases of LASIK, not smile surgery

Visual outcome is similar to laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK)

Horner's syndrome

  • HI : heterochromia iridium (seen only in chronic/congenital cases)
  • P : ptosis (mild)
  • A : anhidrosis
  • M : meiosis
  • E : enophthalmos
  • L : Loss of ciliospinal reflex
  • A : anisocoria

choices.text: You will further look at the cornea to find out any ring in it

questions.text: A 35 year old male comes to you with decrease in vision in BE. It is a painless decrease. His vision is 6/36 and 6/18 in RE and LE respectively. AC is clear, no cells, IOP is normal. He also describes there has been an accident in recent past with a head injury. On looking at SL picture what is the next question comes to your mind.
questions.solution:
• This SL picture is of snowflake cataract, seen in DM.
  • so 1st question to pt would be of a history of ant metabolic disorder like DM

questions.text: A 50 year old female came with painful decrease of vision with redness. She also claims to have colored haloes. She tells similar history in past. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution: • This is typically ACG

choices.text: An altitudinal field in the dominant eye

questions.text: A 64- year-old hypertensive patient complains of difficulty reading. He states, "Things are blurry, I sometimes lose my place when reading, and I still see things after I've looked away" as shown in the picture. Examination demonstrates the acuity of 20/20 OU with normal motility, pupillary, and fundus evaluation. The visual field examination might be expected to show what kind of field defect?
questions.solution:
• This is describing the left sided defects. As pt reads and when come back to read the next line she loose her place where to start again from
  • Also the picture shows left homonymous hemianopia

questions.text: A 26 year old female came to OPD with 6/60 vision in one eye and 6/24 in other with multiple episodes of decrease in vision and recovery with steroids. She also has tranverse myelitis. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: This is optic neuritis which may be associated with Neuromyelitis optica

questions.text: A 20 year male came to you with complaint of discomfort by his glasses and frequent change in number. You observe a sign in him when he is asked to look down which is shown in the picture. All are other signs can be expected in him except
questions.solution:
• Joffroy sign is seen in thyroid ophthalmopathy
  • Rest all signs are seen in keratoconus which is the diagnosis looking at the picture. The sign given here is munson sign.
  • Joffroy's sign is a clinical sign in which there is a lack of wrinkling of the forehead when a patient looks up with the head bent forwards.

choices.text: All of the above is equally responsible

questions.text: A 7 year old boy came with difficulty in copying from blackboard on school. When he visited you the vision was found to be 6/24. What is the most common cause of such a problem
questions.solution:
• This case is of myopia. The MC cause of myopia is larger eye ball (axial myopia)
  • Other type of myopias are index, positional, curvatural

choices.text: Axons of the amacrine cells and dendrites of ganglion cells

questions.text: Which one of the following is found in the inner plexiform layer?
questions.solution:
• The nerve fiber layer contains the axons of the ganglion cells.
  • The inner plexiform layer has axons of the bipolar and amacrine cells and the synapses of the ganglion cells.
  • The outer plexiform layer has connections between the photoreceptors, horizontal cells, and bipolar cells.
  • The footplates of the Muller cells form the internal limiting membrane

questions.text: A patient had a -10 D myopic LASIK treatment years ago. Now, she presents for cataract surgery. All of the following measurements would be helpful in the calculation of the lens power for cataract surgery in this patient except:
questions.solution:
• A number of formulas have been developed to calculate the IOL power after LASIK and refractive surgery, including the Aramberri Double K method, clinical history method, Masket method, and others.
  • These rely upon pre- and postoperative refractions and keratometry, the LASIK treatment, and adjustments to these measurements.
  • Although corneal thickness may influence the curvature of the cornea, the actual corneal curvature measurements and refractions are the most useful in the calculations for lens power post-LASIK.

choices.text: Ocular complications are more as compared to scleritis

questions.text: False about episcleritis
Which of the following is least likely corneal complication associated with VKC?
questions.solution: • Corneal involvement in VKC: Corneal involvement can take the form of punctate epitheliopathy, shield ulcer and secondary keratoconus. Pannus formation is most commonly associated with Trachoma.

questions.text: A 40 year old pt presented with redness and photophobia since 2 days. He also complaint of same sided headache. His vision was 6/6 in both eyes. Anterior segment has flare and KPs. IOP was 26 mmHg. Which antiglaucoma drug has to be avoided
questions.solution:
• To control IOP spikes in uveitis we cant use PG analogues as they are pro inflammatory . As eye is already inflamed we wont use this
  • We can safely use timolol

choices.text: PPV and removal of IOL and intravitreal antibiotic

questions.text: A 60 year old male came with painful red eye. He had a history of phacoemulsification 6 months back and now having a decrease in vision also. On examination his vision was FC at CF, vitritis and anterior uveitis. There is a white plaque also at IOL. What should be the most like management you would like to do
questions.solution:
• This is a case of late onset endophthalmitis caused by P acne
  • Here plaque over IOL is the hint

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium
questions.solution:
• BM cant be regenerated.
  • It's a false acellular layer, it is just a superficial condensed stroma

choices.text: Stress at workplace should be ruled out
There may be history of night blindness
Petalloid appearance can be seen on FFA

questions.text: A young IT professional complaining of metamorphopsia since a month came to your OPD . After the clinical work up you decided to go for an OCT. What is the likely correct statements about this pt
questions.solution: • This is a case of neurosensory detachment in CSR. Here the pt in OCT shows neurosensory detachment. Stress, steroids and smoking are the MI risk factors

questions.text: A 45 year old female came with a Left painful red eye since one day. She has a lot of headache with decreased vision also. The SLE showed this picture. There is a mid dilated pupil also. What is not expected to be seen as a consequence of this ocular condition
questions.solution:
• This is a case of ACG
  • The consequences can be learnt by Vogt triad
  • PIG (pneumonic)
  • Pigments/pupil changes
  • Iris atrophy
  • Glaucomphlecan
  • Iris bombe is seen in uveitis

questions.text: A 75 year old male with hypertension and diabetes underwent cataract 10 days back. His vision is still not clear. He has no redness, pain in the eye but corneal edema is present. On specular microscopy examination his cells had this picture. What can be the cause of this edema
questions.solution: • This picture is of specular microscopy showing a poor endothelium. As the pt is also very old and undergone a cataract surgery which further lead to loss of endothelial cells
